metadata.case_name: Sardul Singh Caveeshar & Ors. v. State

facts.text: Four appellants along with Ramniklal Keshavlal Jhaveri (acquitted) committed for trial on charges of conspiracy to commit criminal breach of trust of funds of Jupiter General Insurance Co. Ltd. (Jupiter) from December 1, 1948 to January 31, 1949, and commission thereof.

Appellants: Sardul Singh Caveeshar (managing director of Peoples Insurance Co.), Parmeshwar Nath Kaul (barrister), Vallabhdas Phulchand Mehta (manager of Bombay office of Tropical Insurance Co. Ltd.), Charucharan Guha (accountant of Tropical).

Lala Shankarlal (deceased, brain behind conspiracy), managing director of Tropical Insurance Co. Ltd. (Tropical, financially tottering), planned to acquire controlling block of Jupiter shares (about 63,000 shares at Rs. 53 per share, total Rs. 33,39,000) using Jupiter's own funds.
Agreement dated December 29, 1948: Rs. 5,39,000 cash advance (Rs. 4,85,000 paid to Bajaj), balance Rs. 28 lakhs by January 20, 1949, or Rs. 5 lakhs damages.
On December 29, 1948, 1,250 qualifying shares allotted to Lala Shankarlal, Kaul, Mehta, Jhaveri, Doshi; old directors resigned, new group appointed, Lala Shankarlal as managing director.

January 11, 1949 meeting: Resolutions to sell securities Rs. 15 lakhs, overdraft Rs. 14 lakhs on pledge, loan Rs. 25,15,000 to Caveeshar on equitable mortgage of Delhi properties, purchase plots from Delhi Stores (defunct, controlled by Lala Shankarlal) for Rs. 2,60,000.

Securities withdrawn from Bank of India safe custody to Mehta's personal custody; Rs. 15 lakhs securities sold realizing Rs. 13,99,768; Rs. 14 lakhs overdraft from Punjab National Bank Delhi on Lala Shankarlal's application.
Total Rs. 28,21,580 raised from Jupiter securities used to pay Rs. 28,15,000 to Khaitan via camouflaged cheques from Jupiter to Tropical/Delhi Stores, routed back.
Sessions Judge convicted appellants: Caveeshar 3 years RI + Rs.2500 fine; Kaul and Mehta 5 years RI + Rs.5000 fine each; Guha 3 years RI + Rs.2500 fine. Jury majority/unanimous verdicts accepted.
Bombay High Court upheld convictions on November 21, 1956.

Second period (Feb-Dec 1949): Manipulations to show repayment of Caveeshar loan and Delhi Stores advance: Raghavji loan, fresh Caveeshar loan, Misri Devi loan, purchase 54,000 Tropical shares, totaling adjustments to wipe out Rs.25,10,650.
1950: Auditors queried loans; directors manipulated using control of Empire of India shares acquired similarly, to show repayments in cash.
Distribution of 63,000 Jupiter shares among conspirators and nominees without payment.

legal_issues.text: Admissibility of evidence of acts, statements post-conspiracy period (1950 transactions) under s.10 Evidence Act, or ss.6,8,9,11,14.
Whether 1950 evidence relevant to prove bogus nature of January 1949 transactions and criminal intent.

petitioner_arguments.text: Evidence of 1950 transactions inadmissible under s.10 Evidence Act as outside conspiracy period (Dec 1948-Jan 1949); too remote, confuses jury, prejudices appellants.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.10 Indian Evidence Act; Mirza Akbar v. The King-Emperor

petitioner_arguments.text: Post-1949 evidence screens 1949 transactions, not original conspiracy; acts of deceased Lala Shankarlal inadmissible against others.

respondent_arguments.text: 1950 evidence admissible to prove bogus character of original transactions and criminal intent of each accused; relevant under ss.6,8,9,11,14 Evidence Act.
Transactions integrally connected; rebuts defence of innocent participation.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.14 Indian Evidence Act; Makin v. Attorney-General

court_reasoning.text: s.10 Evidence Act limits to acts during conspiracy period in reference to common intention; 1950 evidence outside period not admissible under s.10 but relevant under other sections to prove bogus transactions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence admissible to show original transactions bogus and rebut innocent intent defence.

court_reasoning.text: Trial judge correctly distinguished; charged jury on limits; no prejudice shown as Jhaveri acquitted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Jury capable of discrimination despite complexity.

holdings.text: Evidence of 1950 transactions admissible under ss.6,8,9,11,14 Evidence Act to prove bogus nature of January 1949 transactions and criminal intent.

precedents_cited.relevance: Limits s.10 Evidence Act to acts during conspiracy carrying out common intention.
Sections like s.11 require limited construction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Makin v. The Attorney-General for New South Wales
precedents_cited.relevance: Prosecution may lead rebuttal evidence of likely defence on intention.
Caution on prejudice from evidence admissible against one not others, but not vitiating absent serious prejudice.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Admissibility of post-conspiracy acts in conspiracy and criminal breach of trust case.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court considers appeals by special leave against High Court upholding Sessions Judge convictions; holds 1950 evidence admissible, overrules appellants' main contention on inadmissibility.

key_quotes.text: "s. 10 of the Evidence Act must be construed in accordance with the principle that the thing done, written, or spoken, was something done in carrying out the conspiracy and was receivable as a step in the proof of the conspiracy."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of s.10 Evidence Act from Mirza Akbar.

key_quotes.text: "evidence receivable under s. 10 ... must be in reference to their common intention."
key_quotes.speaker: court
